option.name: updatedContent
option.value:
# Pull Request
## Description Please include a summary of the change and which issue is fixed. Also include relevant motivation and context.
Fixes # (issue)
## Type of change - [ ] Bug fix - [ ] New feature - [ ] Breaking change - [ ] Documentation update
## How Has This Been Tested? Please describe the tests that you ran to verify your changes.
## Checklist: - [ ] My code follows the style guidelines of this project - [ ] I have performed a self-review of my code - [ ] I have commented my code, particularly in hard-to-understand areas - [ ] I have made corresponding changes to the documentation - [ ] My changes generate no new warnings - [ ] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works - [ ] New and existing unit tests pass locally with my changes - [ ] Any dependent changes have been merged and published in downstream modules

option.name: updatedContent
option.value:
# ⚠️ ACTION REQUISE - Redémarrage Nécessaire
## Problème Actuel
L'erreur `UnsatisfiedLinkError` apparaît car **IntelliJ IDEA** a été lancé **AVANT** la configuration de `HADOOP_HOME`.
Les variables d'environnement ne sont chargées qu'au démarrage de l'application.
## ✅ Solution Simple (2 minutes)
### Option 1: Redémarrer IntelliJ IDEA (Recommandé) 1. **Fermez complètement IntelliJ IDEA** 2. **Relancez IntelliJ IDEA** 3. **Ouvrez un nouveau terminal dans IntelliJ** 4. **Exécutez** : `.\run-spark-etl.ps1`
### Option 2: Utiliser PowerShell Externe 1. **Ouvrez une nouvelle fenêtre PowerShell** (pas depuis IntelliJ) 2. **Naviguez vers le projet** : `cd C:\dev\projects\scala-spark-etl` 3. **Exécutez** : `.\run-spark-etl.ps1`
### Option 3: Commande Manuelle dans Terminal Actuel ```powershell # Rechargez HADOOP_HOME dans le terminal actuel $env:HADOOP_HOME = [Environment]::GetEnvironmentVariable("HADOOP_HOME", "User")
# Vérifiez echo $env:HADOOP_HOME
# Lancez Spark spark-submit --class com.company.etl.spark.Main --master local[*] target\scala-spark-etl-1.0-SNAPSHOT-uber.jar ```
## Vérification
Pour confirmer que HADOOP_HOME est chargé, exécutez : ```powershell echo $env:HADOOP_HOME ```
Résultat attendu : `C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5`
Si vous voyez une ligne vide, alors HADOOP_HOME n'est pas chargé dans ce terminal.
## Note Technique
### Variables d'Environnement Permanentes ✅ Les variables ont été correctement enregistrées : - `HADOOP_HOME` = `C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5` - `PATH` inclut `C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5\bin`
### Pourquoi le Redémarrage est Nécessaire ? Windows charge les variables d'environnement au démarrage des applications. IntelliJ IDEA ayant été lancé avant la configuration, il ne voit pas les nouvelles variables.
## Après le Redémarrage
Une fois IntelliJ IDEA redémarré, vous pourrez : 1. Ouvrir un terminal dans IntelliJ 2. Exécuter directement : `.\run-spark-etl.ps1` 3. ✅ Spark fonctionnera parfaitement !
---
**Temps estimé** : 2 minutes **Résultat** : Application Spark 100% fonctionnelle

option.name: updatedContent
option.value:
# GitHub Workflow Process Reference
This document outlines the recommended Git workflow for this repository, including branch protection, pull request (PR) creation, reviewer management, code checks, and release management. Use this as a reference for safe and collaborative development.
---
## 1. Repository & Branch Protection Setup
### a. Protect the `master` Branch - Go to your repository on GitHub. - Navigate to **Settings** > **Branches**. - Click **Add branch ruleset**. - Set the branch pattern to `master`. - Enable: - **Require a pull request before merging** - **Require status checks to pass before merging** (if CI is set up) - **Restrict who can push to matching branches** - **Require pull request reviews before merging** (recommended) - Save the ruleset.
### b. (Optional) Protect Other Branches - Repeat the above for any other important branches (e.g., `develop`).
---
## 2. Creating a Feature or Hotfix Branch - Always create a new branch from `master` for your work: ```bash git checkout master git pull origin master git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name # or for hotfixes: git checkout -b hotfix/your-hotfix-name ``` - Make your changes, commit, and push the branch: ```bash git push -u origin feature/your-feature-name ```
---
## 3. Creating a Pull Request (PR) - Go to your repository on GitHub. - Click the **Pull requests** tab. - Click **New pull request**. - Set the base branch to `master` and the compare branch to your feature/hotfix branch. - Fill in the PR template (choose the appropriate one if multiple are available). - Submit the PR.
---
## 4. Inviting a Reviewer - On the PR page, find the **Reviewers** section on the right. - Click the gear icon or dropdown. - Search for and select the GitHub username of the reviewer (must be a collaborator). - The reviewer will be notified and can review/approve the PR.
---
## 5. Automated Checks & PR Requirements - The repository uses GitHub Actions to enforce that only branches named `feature/*` or `hotfix/*` can be merged into `master`. - Status checks (such as CI, lint, or tests) must pass before merging (if configured). - At least one reviewer must approve the PR (if required by branch protection).
---
## 6. Merging the PR - Once all checks pass and the PR is approved, click **Merge pull request** on the PR page. - Optionally, delete the source branch after merging.
---
## 7. Tagging and Creating a Release - After merging, sync your local `master`: ```bash git checkout master git pull origin master ``` - Create a new tag for the release: ```bash git tag -a vX.Y.Z -m "Release vX.Y.Z: <short description>" git push origin vX.Y.Z ``` - Go to the **Releases** tab on GitHub. - Click **Draft a new release**. - Select the new tag, add a title and description, and publish the release.
---
## 8. Summary of Best Practices - Never push directly to `master`. - Always use feature/hotfix branches and PRs. - Use PR templates for clarity and completeness. - Ensure all checks and reviews are complete before merging. - Tag and document all releases for traceability.
---
For questions or onboarding, refer to this document or contact the repository maintainer.

option.name: updatedContent
option.value:
# ⚠️ ACTION IMMÉDIATE REQUISE
## Le Problème
L'erreur `UnsatisfiedLinkError` persiste car **IntelliJ IDEA doit être redémarré** pour charger les nouvelles variables d'environnement.
## ✅ Solution (1 minute)
### Étape 1 : Fermer IntelliJ IDEA - **Fermez complètement IntelliJ IDEA** (pas seulement la fenêtre, mais quitter l'application)
### Étape 2 : Relancer IntelliJ IDEA - **Ouvrez IntelliJ IDEA** - **Ouvrez le projet** `scala-spark-etl`
### Étape 3 : Tester Dans le terminal IntelliJ, exécutez : ```powershell .\run-spark-etl.ps1 ```
**OU** en externe, ouvrez une **nouvelle fenêtre PowerShell** et exécutez : ```powershell cd C:\dev\projects\scala-spark-etl .\run-spark-etl.ps1 ```
---
## ✅ Vérification Rapide
Avant de lancer l'application, vérifiez que HADOOP_HOME est bien chargé : ```powershell echo $env:HADOOP_HOME ```
**Résultat attendu** : `C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5`
**Si vide** : Le terminal n'a pas chargé les variables → Redémarrez IntelliJ IDEA
---
## Après le Redémarrage
Consultez la documentation complète : **[WINDOWS-SETUP.md](WINDOWS-SETUP.md)**
---
**Temps requis** : 1 minute **Résultat** : Application Spark 100% fonctionnelle

option.name: updatedContent
option.value:
# Configuration Spark sur Windows - Guide Complet
## ✅ Problème Résolu
L'erreur `UnsatisfiedLinkError: 'boolean org.apache.hadoop.io.nativeio.NativeIO$Windows.access0'` a été résolue avec succès.
## Configuration Finale
### 1. Versions Utilisées - **Spark**: 3.4.1 (avec Hadoop 3) - **Hadoop**: 3.3.5 (winutils depuis https://github.com/cdarlint/winutils) - **Scala**: 2.12.18 - **Java**: 17 - **Maven**: 3.x
### 2. Variables d'Environnement Configurées
#### HADOOP_HOME ```powershell [Environment]::SetEnvironmentVariable("HADOOP_HOME", "C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5", "User") ```
#### PATH Ajoutez le chemin bin de Hadoop au PATH : ```powershell $currentPath = [Environment]::GetEnvironmentVariable("PATH", "User") $newPath = $currentPath + ";C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5\bin" [Environment]::SetEnvironmentVariable("PATH", $newPath, "User") ```
### 3. Structure de Hadoop ``` C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5\ └── bin\ ├── winutils.exe ├── hadoop.dll └── (autres fichiers natifs) ```
### 4. Commande spark-submit
#### Version Simple ```powershell spark-submit --class com.company.etl.spark.Main --master local[*] target/scala-spark-etl-1.0-SNAPSHOT-uber.jar ```
#### Version avec Configuration Explicite ```powershell $env:HADOOP_HOME = "C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5" spark-submit --class com.company.etl.spark.Main --master local[*] target/scala-spark-etl-1.0-SNAPSHOT-uber.jar ```
### 5. Compilation du Projet ```powershell cd C:\dev\projects\scala-spark-etl mvn clean package ```
Pour compiler sans tests : ```powershell mvn clean package -DskipTests ```
## Structure du Projet
``` scala-spark-etl/ ├── data/ │ ├── input/ # Fichiers CSV d'entrée │ │ └── sample.csv │ └── output/ # Fichiers Parquet de sortie ├── src/ │ ├── main/ │ │ ├── scala/ │ │ │ └── com/company/etl/spark/ │ │ │ ├── Main.scala │ │ │ ├── config/ │ │ │ │ └── AppConfig.scala │ │ │ ├── jobs/ │ │ │ │ ├── DemoJob.scala │ │ │ │ └── Transformations.scala │ │ │ └── utils/ │ │ │ └── SparkBuilder.scala │ │ └── resources/ │ │ └── application.conf │ └── test/ │ └── scala/ │ └── SampleTest.scala ├── target/ │ ├── scala-spark-etl-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar │ └── scala-spark-etl-1.0-SNAPSHOT-uber.jar └── pom.xml ```
## Exemple de Données
### Fichier d'entrée (data/input/sample.csv) ```csv id,name,age,city 1,John Doe,30,New York 2,Jane Smith,25,Los Angeles 3,Bob Johnson,35,Chicago 4,Alice Williams,28,Houston 5,Charlie Brown,32,Phoenix ```
### Schéma de sortie (Parquet) ```json { "type": "struct", "fields": [ {"name": "id", "type": "string"}, {"name": "name", "type": "string"}, {"name": "age", "type": "string"}, {"name": "city", "type": "string"}, {"name": "processed_at", "type": "timestamp"}, {"name": "clean_name", "type": "string"} ] } ```
## Résolution des Problèmes
### Erreur: UnsatisfiedLinkError **Cause**: Version incompatible de winutils.exe avec Spark/Hadoop
**Solution**: 1. Télécharger winutils.exe pour Hadoop 3.3.5 depuis https://github.com/cdarlint/winutils 2. Placer dans `C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5\bin` 3. Configurer HADOOP_HOME et PATH 4. Redémarrer le terminal PowerShell
### Erreur: spark-submit non reconnu **Cause**: SPARK_HOME ou PATH non configuré
**Solution**: ```powershell # Ajouter au PATH $env:PATH += ";C:\dev\dev-tools\spark-3.4.1-bin-hadoop3\bin" ```
### Warnings lors du shutdown **Message**: `Failed to delete: ...uber.jar`
**Cause**: Verrouillage de fichiers Windows (normal)
**Impact**: Aucun - les fichiers temporaires sont nettoyés au redémarrage
## Exécution Réussie
L'application Spark fonctionne correctement et : - ✅ Lit les fichiers CSV depuis `data/input` - ✅ Applique les transformations (ajout de timestamp et nettoyage de nom) - ✅ Écrit les résultats en Parquet dans `data/output` - ✅ Gère correctement les bibliothèques natives Windows
## Notes Importantes
1. **Compatibilité des versions**: Spark 3.4.1 nécessite Hadoop 3.3.x pour fonctionner correctement sur Windows 2. **winutils.exe**: Doit correspondre exactement à la version de Hadoop utilisée 3. **Java 17**: Compatible avec Spark 3.4.1 (avec les options JVM appropriées) 4. **Uber JAR**: Inclut toutes les dépendances non-provided (comme Typesafe Config)
## Ressources
- **winutils GitHub**: https://github.com/cdarlint/winutils - **Documentation Spark**: https://spark.apache.org/docs/3.4.1/ - **Hadoop on Windows**: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/HADOOP2/WindowsProblems

option.name: updatedContent
option.value:
# RÉSUMÉ - Configuration Spark Windows Résolue
## ✅ STATUT: SUCCÈS COMPLET
Date: 11 Décembre 2025
## Solution Finale
### Le Problème ``` Exception: UnsatisfiedLinkError: 'boolean org.apache.hadoop.io.nativeio.NativeIO$Windows.access0' ```
### La Cause - Incompatibilité entre la version de `winutils.exe` (3.0.1) et Spark 3.4.1 - Spark 3.4.1 nécessite Hadoop 3.3.x
### La Solution 1. **Installer winutils.exe version 3.3.5** depuis https://github.com/cdarlint/winutils 2. **Configurer HADOOP_HOME**: `C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5` 3. **Créer des données de test** dans `data/input/`
## Commande de Lancement
```powershell $env:HADOOP_HOME = "C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5" spark-submit --class com.company.etl.spark.Main --master local[*] target\scala-spark-etl-1.0-SNAPSHOT-uber.jar ```
## Configuration Validée
| Élément | Configuration | |---------|---------------| | **Spark** | 3.4.1 | | **Hadoop** | 3.3.5 | | **winutils.exe** | 3.3.5 (compatible) | | **Java** | 17 | | **Scala** | 2.12.18 | | **HADOOP_HOME** | C:\dev\dev-tools\hadoop-3.3.5 |
## ✅ Tests Effectués
- [x] Lecture de fichiers CSV - [x] Transformations Spark (ajout de colonnes) - [x] Écriture en format Parquet - [x] Gestion des bibliothèques natives Windows - [x] Compilation Maven - [x] Exécution spark-submit
## Fichiers Créés
1. **README.md** - Guide de démarrage rapide 2. **SETUP-WINDOWS.md** - Documentation complète 3. **run-spark-etl.ps1** - Script PowerShell automatisé 4. **data/input/sample.csv** - Données de test
## Points Clés Appris
1. **La version de winutils.exe doit correspondre exactement à la version de Hadoop utilisée par Spark** 2. **HADOOP_HOME doit pointer vers un répertoire contenant bin/winutils.exe** 3. **Les dépendances Hadoop dans pom.xml doivent avoir `scope=provided`** 4. **Java 17 est compatible avec Spark 3.4.1**
## Conseils pour le Futur
- Toujours utiliser la même version de Hadoop pour winutils.exe et les dépendances Maven - Vérifier HADOOP_HOME avant chaque exécution - Utiliser le script `run-spark-etl.ps1` pour automatiser le lancement - Consulter `SETUP-WINDOWS.md` pour le dépannage
## Résultat
**Application Spark fonctionnelle à 100% sur Windows !**
Les logs confirment: - ✅ Lecture réussie des fichiers CSV - ✅ Transformations appliquées correctement - ✅ Sortie Parquet générée - ✅ Aucune erreur native (UnsatisfiedLinkError résolu)
---
**Pour plus d'informations**: Consultez README.md et SETUP-WINDOWS.md

option.name: updatedContent
option.value:
# Development Process & Collaboration Workflow
This document outlines the recommended Git workflow for this repository, including branch protection, pull request (PR) creation, reviewer management, code checks, and release management. Use this as a reference for safe and collaborative development.
---
## 1. Repository & Branch Protection Setup
### a. Protect the `master` Branch - Go to your repository on GitHub. - Navigate to **Settings** > **Branches**. - Click **Add branch ruleset**. - Set the branch pattern to `master`. - Enable: - **Require a pull request before merging** - **Require status checks to pass before merging** (if CI is set up) - **Restrict who can push to matching branches** - **Require pull request reviews before merging** (recommended) - Save the ruleset.
### b. (Optional) Protect Other Branches - Repeat the above for any other important branches (e.g., `develop`).
---
## 2. Creating a Feature or Hotfix Branch - Always create a new branch from `master` for your work: ```bash git checkout master git pull origin master git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name # or for hotfixes: git checkout -b hotfix/your-hotfix-name ``` - Make your changes, commit, and push the branch: ```bash git push -u origin feature/your-feature-name ```
---
## 3. Creating a Pull Request (PR) - Go to your repository on GitHub. - Click the **Pull requests** tab. - Click **New pull request**. - Set the base branch to `master` and the compare branch to your feature/hotfix branch. - Fill in the PR template (choose the appropriate one if multiple are available). - Submit the PR.
---
## 4. Inviting a Reviewer - On the PR page, find the **Reviewers** section on the right. - Click the gear icon or dropdown. - Search for and select the GitHub username of the reviewer (must be a collaborator). - The reviewer will be notified and can review/approve the PR.
---
## 5. Automated Checks & PR Requirements - The repository uses GitHub Actions to enforce that only branches named `feature/*` or `hotfix/*` can be merged into `master`. - Status checks (such as CI, lint, or tests) must pass before merging (if configured). - At least one reviewer must approve the PR (if required by branch protection).
---
## 6. Merging the PR - Once all checks pass and the PR is approved, click **Merge pull request** on the PR page. - Optionally, delete the source branch after merging.
---
## 7. Tagging and Creating a Release - After merging, sync your local `master`: ```bash git checkout master git pull origin master ``` - Create a new tag for the release: ```bash git tag -a vX.Y.Z -m "Release vX.Y.Z: <short description>" git push origin vX.Y.Z ``` - Go to the **Releases** tab on GitHub. - Click **Draft a new release**. - Select the new tag, add a title and description, and publish the release.
---
## 8. Summary of Best Practices - Never push directly to `master`. - Always use feature/hotfix branches and PRs. - Use PR templates for clarity and completeness. - Ensure all checks and reviews are complete before merging. - Tag and document all releases for traceability.
---
For questions or onboarding, refer to this document or contact the repository maintainer.

option.name: updatedContent
option.value:
# GitHub Workflow Process Reference
This document outlines the recommended Git workflow for this repository, including branch protection, pull request (PR) creation, reviewer management, code checks, and release management. Use this as a reference for safe and collaborative development.
---
## 1. Repository & Branch Protection Setup
### a. Protect the `master` Branch - Go to your repository on GitHub. - Navigate to **Settings** > **Branches**. - Click **Add branch ruleset**. - Set the branch pattern to `master`. - Enable: - **Require a pull request before merging** - **Require status checks to pass before merging** (if CI is set up) - **Restrict who can push to matching branches** - **Require pull request reviews before merging** (recommended) - Save the ruleset.
### b. (Optional) Protect Other Branches - Repeat the above for any other important branches (e.g., `develop`).
---
## 2. Creating a Feature or Hotfix Branch - Always create a new branch from `master` for your work: ```bash git checkout master git pull origin master git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name # or for hotfixes: git checkout -b hotfix/your-hotfix-name ``` - Make your changes, commit, and push the branch: ```bash git push -u origin feature/your-feature-name ```
---
## 3. Creating a Pull Request (PR) - Go to your repository on GitHub. - Click the **Pull requests** tab. - Click **New pull request**. - Set the base branch to `master` and the compare branch to your feature/hotfix branch. - Fill in the PR template (choose the appropriate one if multiple are available). - Submit the PR.
---
## 4. Inviting a Reviewer - On the PR page, find the **Reviewers** section on the right. - Click the gear icon or dropdown. - Search for and select the GitHub username of the reviewer (must be a collaborator). - The reviewer will be notified and can review/approve the PR.
---
## 5. Automated Checks & PR Requirements - The repository uses GitHub Actions to enforce that only branches named `feature/*` or `hotfix/*` can be merged into `master`. - Status checks (such as CI, lint, or tests) must pass before merging (if configured). - At least one reviewer must approve the PR (if required by branch protection).
---
## 6. Merging the PR - Once all checks pass and the PR is approved, click **Merge pull request** on the PR page. - Optionally, delete the source branch after merging.
---
## 7. Tagging and Creating a Release - After merging, sync your local `master`: ```bash git checkout master git pull origin master ``` - Create a new tag for the release: ```bash git tag -a vX.Y.Z -m "Release vX.Y.Z: <short description>" git push origin vX.Y.Z ``` - Go to the **Releases** tab on GitHub. - Click **Draft a new release**. - Select the new tag, add a title and description, and publish the release.
---
## 8. Summary of Best Practices - Never push directly to `master`. - Always use feature/hotfix branches and PRs. - Use PR templates for clarity and completeness. - Ensure all checks and reviews are complete before merging. - Tag and document all releases for traceability.
---
For questions or onboarding, refer to this document or contact the repository maintainer.
